p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 26th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 22 April, 15 May and 29 May 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 54 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 184 petitioners—requesting a nationwide cap on rental price increases (EN6068)
From 15 petitioners—requesting rail infrastructure upgrades for regional Queensland (EN6069)
From 14 petitioners—requesting honorary Australian citizenship be awarded to Formula One driver Valtteri Bottas (EN6071)
From 29 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government assist consumers with the price of groceries (EN6072)
From 32 petitioners—regarding legislation related to vaping (EN6074)
From 543 petitioners—requesting transparency about any form of Australian aid provided to Israel (EN6075)
From 31 petitioners—regarding conversion therapy and the rights of transgender individuals (EN6077)
From 5 petitioners—requesting an inquiry into the National Broadband Network (EN6078)
From 10114 petitioners—requesting legislation be implemented to protect consumer rights for digital software (EN6080)
From 39 petitioners—requesting that a proposed ban on citizens from Iran and Iraq entering Australia be abandoned (EN6082)
From 38 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN6083)
From 77 petitioners—regarding concerns about the responsiveness and efficiency of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN6084)
From 1059 petitioners—regarding costs, waiting times and quotas for parent visas (EN6085)
From 17 petitioners—requesting that legal aid be accessible for family court matters involving the custody of children (EN6086)
From 263 petitioners—requesting that the proposed construction of an offshore windfarm at Geographe Bay be rejected (EN6087)
From 35 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN6088)
From 22 petitioners—requesting a review into legislation related to privacy laws (EN6090)
From 4543 petitioners—requesting the rejection of the Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024 (EN6091)
From 65 petitioners—regarding employment requirements for Skilled Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visa holders (EN6093)
From 9 petitioners—regarding access to public and private spaces for companion dogs (EN6094)
From 4 petitioners—requesting tax rebates to offset the cost of energy bills (EN6095)
From 63 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN6097)
From 1440 petitioners—requesting the cancellation of all offshore wind turbine proposals and projects (EN6098)
From 9 petitioners—requesting that all Boeing 737-Max airplanes be grounded due to safety concerns (EN6099)
From 12 petitioners—regarding recognition of Australia's constitutional monarchy (EN6100)
From 60 petitioners—regarding sex education for children (EN6101)
From 311 petitioners—requesting that the number of Medicare rebated psychology sessions be increased to 20 (EN6102)
From 17 petitioners—requesting support for Israel from the Australian Government (EN6103)
From 15 petitioners—requesting that boomerang throwing be recognised as an official sport in Australia (EN6104)
From 160 petitioners—requesting the expulsion of the Israeli Ambassador to Australia (EN6105)

From 16391 petitioners—requesting that Australia cease diplomatic relations with Israel, cease military exports to Israel, terminate all contracts with Elbit Systems, condemn the deaths of Palestinian civilians in Gaza and support South Africa's case against Israel at the International Court of Justice (EN6106)
From 17 petitioners—regarding management of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN6107)
From 3 petitioners—requesting the development of a nuclear fusion energy industry in Australia (EN6108)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the development of a nuclear fusion energy industry in Australia (EN6109)
From 4 petitioners—requesting the development of a nuclear fusion energy industry in Australia (EN6110)
From 324 petitioners—requesting independent oversight of the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency and the Medical Board of Australia (EN6113)
From 1116 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN6115)
From 59 petitioners—regarding Employer Nomination Scheme (subclass 186) visa applicants (EN6116)
From 26 petitioners—requesting that drospirenone be added to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (EN6117)
From 84 petitioners—requesting that the severity of criminal penalties for child sex offenders be increased (EN6118)
From 426 petitioners—requesting that all immigration be suspended (EN6119)
From 43 petitioners—requesting that the pending shutdown of the 3G network be suspended (EN6120)
From 50 petitioners—regarding the Australian Government's Net Zero Plan (EN6121)
From 113 petitioners—requesting information about the memorandum of understanding signed by Australia and Israel in 2017 (EN6122)
From 68 petitioners—regarding concerns related to the 5G network and associated infrastructure (EN6123)
From 2189 petitioners—regarding the accessibility of reusable cannabis vaping devices (EN6127)
From 70 petitioners—requesting that the Taliban be proscribed as a terrorist organisation (EN6128)
From 22 petitioners—requesting that olaparib be added to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for the treatment of pancreatic cancer (EN6130)
From 307 petitioners—requesting legislation to protect the Great Artesian Basin (EN6134)
From 16 petitioners—regarding Israeli refugees (EN6136)
From 237 petitioners—regarding the power that the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship has to cancel the visas of non-citizens on character grounds (EN6138)
From 27 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a National Day of Unity in Australia (EN6139)
From 35 petitioners—requesting that Australia ratify the United Nations Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (PN0606)
From 1318 petitioners—requesting that an F/A-18 'Classic' Hornet be allocated to the Queensland Air Museum (PN0608)

span.span: 2. The following 26 ministerial responses to petitions were received.
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 15 May 2024

From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that whistleblower protections be strengthened (EN5691)
From the Minister for Finance to a petition regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN5749)
From the Minister for Finance to a petition regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN5751)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that the Australian Government legislate to prevent Australian citizens from serving in the Israel Defense Forces (EN5771)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding the Australian Securities and Investments Commission supervisory cost recovery levy (EN5784)

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 54 petitions:
Housing
Rental price increases are putting Australians on the street, in cars, tents, couches and under bridges.
Current rental crises is hard enough, stop landlords and agents from taking advantage of the situation.
When does it stop?
The government needs to step in and put regulations in place to stop this and even reduce what has already happened.
We therefore ask the House to regulate the housing rental increases.
Put a limit on how much of an increase is allowed and a time limit.
For eg 2% every 24 months.
Form an independent body to oversea compliance as well as an independent assessments in regards to excessive rental prices and enforcing legislation to prevent over charging and non compliance.
This would be a federal legislation.
from 184 citizens (Petition No. EN6068)
Queensland: Rail Transport

Rail usage needs to be boosted in Queensland to get more cars off the Bruce Highway which will lower maintanence costs and reduce the risk of crashes, the North Coast Railway Line has had very little major investment since the 1990's, and the travel times are long. Sections of track between Townsville and Rockhampton need to be re-aligned and grading improved as well as grade seperation of crossings and rationalization of rural crossings to allow faster (160km/hr and above) and more frequent services to run with the eventual plan to duplicate and electrify the line to separate passenger and freight traffic. I single out the section between Townsville and Rockhampton as this section is mostly flat and the SEQ network already is duplicated and has electrification. The section north of Townsville has complex topography that would push costs even higher. This project would reduce travel times between Regional Cities and allow for better connections with South East Queensland and would result in transformative economic co-operation, increased productivity, and better social cohesion between North and South East Queensland helping to stave off calls for a seperate NQ State.

We therefore ask the House to work with the Queensland State Government on providing resources and funding to commence investigative and design works for this and to then provide funding for construction as it did to projects such as Cross River Rail and the Brisbane Olympics etc. Regional Queensland is just as deserving of transformative projects as South East Queensland.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN6069)
Bottas, Mr Valtteri Viktor

We, the undersigned, believe that Valtteri Bottas, the esteemed mullet-sporting Formula One racing driver, is a dead set Aussie legend. He has demonstrated unparalleled skill, sportsmanship, and dedication throughout his career. As such, we petition the Australian government to consider granting him Australian nationality as a gesture of appreciation for his contributions to motorsport and his popularity among Australian fans (and his mullet).

Valtteri Bottas has showcased exceptional talent on the global stage, representing his team and country with pride and professionalism. His participation in events such as the Australian Grand Prix has brought excitement and joy to countless fans across the nation. Granting him Australian nationality would not only honor his achievements but also strengthen the bond between Australia and the international motorsport community.

We believe that Valtteri Bottas embodies the values of humour, determination, excellence, and camaraderie that are cherished by Australians. By welcoming him as an honorary Australian, we celebrate diversity, inclusivity, and the spirit of competition that transcends borders.
We urge the Australian government to recognize Valtteri Bottas's remarkable talent and contribution to motorsport by granting him Australian nationality. But it's mostly the mullet
We therefore ask the House to debate the issuance of honourary citizenship to Valtteri Bottas
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6071)
Grocery Prices

The cost of groceries is a leading cause of stress for many Australians. Despite government initiatives such as empowering the ACCC with a 12-month inquiry into the Australian supermarket sector and the Senate Select Committee on Supermarket Prices, these measures fail to address the immediate needs of Australians struggling to save money on groceries.

The Treasury were contacted and are unwilling to consider my application to save people money on groceries. Checks with external agencies who deal with government procurement confirm there are no available grants or tenders available for my proposal.
We therefore ask the House to support the use of government procurements through The Treasury, to provide funding to achieve savings on grocery costs.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN6072)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
Government wanting to ban vaping products is a direct attack on rights and freedoms
We therefore ask the House to legalise and regulate vaping product and not remove rights and freedoms.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN6074)
International Relations: Australia and Israel
Right of freedom of information to taxpayers to know how much of our taxes have been given and still continue (against international law) to Israel

We therefore ask the House to provide full disclosure of total amount either given directly to Israel or via US and UK as financial aid and also how much money is spent on military aid over the last six months. The house is fully aware that Australians overwhelmingly support the unarmed, innocent civilians of Palestine making it even more imperative to have this financial disclosure of our taxes
from 543 citizens (Petition No. EN6075)
Gender and Sexual Orientation

The reason for this petition is we see places like Catholic Education Tasmania And Other Catholic Schools attempting secret conversion therapy and outright treating queer people as less that human, it has been proven that being queer is not a choice, yet this places try to persuade our community that it is a choice and a bad choice at that they threaten to shut down anyone who does not agree with them and their views. we see repetitive political parties such as pauline hanson's one nation try to create transphobic and homophobic laws, we see people like her call it a choice BUT WE KNOW IT IS NOT, she says that we need to protect our children but to protect them we need to accept them in stated of treating queer kids like they are going through a phase. Queer people exist and we need to accept that they always have existed even in aboriginal culture we see Brotherboy and sistergirl which are the terms for transgender people. Trans girls are girls and trenas boys are boys, ITS NOT THE PARTS THAT MAKE YOU YOU IT IS OUR PERSONALITY, We Need Aceptence.
We therefore ask the House to stop the allowing companies to pitch laws like how CET is asking for conversion therapy. Trans rights Are Human Rights.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN6077)
Broadband

In 2020, the Government of the day touted that the rollout of the NBN was complete. However, many Australians have been left stranded without access to this vital "Government-planned" cyberinfrastructure and are now forcibly dependent on an aging and snail-paced ADSL and/or 3G network. The reason behind this petition is well summed up in this May 08, 2022, Guardian article, 'They will do nothing to fix it': why the NBN still matters to many voters. And more recently, by the Federal Communications Minister in news articles about the shutdown of the 3G network. In 2024—these (very real & debilitating) issues still plague many Australian households (recent data suggests at least 750,000). Those now reliant on an ailing network because they cannot connect to the NBN are stranded in virtual communications paralysis. This compromises their health and safety and stifles business productivity too, particularly those operating in a home-based environment or from regional or remote localities.

We therefore ask the House to implement an independent national review of NBN infrastructure capabilities and failings to determine the overall customer experience and levels of connectivity throughout Australia.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6078)
Consumer Protection: Digital Products

An increasing number of software companies (foreign and local) publish software that is arbitrarily required to 'phone home' in order to function. This is especially prevalent in entertainment software such as videogames.

Unlike normal software, when a publisher discontinues such products they do not simply end development and technical support—instead, they choose to render all copies of the software inoperable, effectively withdrawing customers' rights under the Australian Consumer Law to ownership and undisturbed possession of their purchased goods.
Many companies go to great lengths to prevent customers restoring their property to working order, withholding vital components of their function from end users.

These practices rob customers of the product they fairly purchased, and make restoration and preservation impossible. Due to the technical nature of software products and current legislative ambiguity, clearer legislation is needed.
We therefore ask the House to enact legislation to:
1. Require software sold in Australia to remain in a functional state after the end of the product's support period, continuing to operate without any intervention from the publisher.

2. Require publishers selling additional features/assets for their software to leave said software in a functional state after the end of the product's support period, so customers can continue to utilise features/assets they purchased without any intervention from the publisher.

3. Establish that these requirements supercede software End-User License Agreements, as many such licenses attempt to strip customers' right to ownership over their purchased goods, as guaranteed under schedule 2 of the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.
from 10,114 citizens (Petition No. EN6080)

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024

p.span: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024

We urge the Australian government to abandon its proposed ban on Iranian and Iraqi citizens, a law that unjustly punishes individuals for their governments' actions. Such discrimination, based on nationality, contradicts Australia's values of fairness, equality, and compassion, fostering xenophobia. We call for policies reflecting inclusivity and human rights, advocating for dialogue with impacted communities to find humane solutions. This petition stands for unity, respecting individuals' dignity and rights, emphasizing their potential over their governments' decisions.
We therefore ask the House to repeal this legislation.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN6082)
Personal Information and Privacy
Reasons for this is for the rights and freedoms inherent within the person to remain free and unhindered in their free movement of conducting their lives
We therefore ask the House to respectfully hear the citizens of Australia and assist them in their will to step away from the forced use of digital ID
from 38 citizens (Petition No. EN6083)
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Participants face challenges accessing continuity of care during crisis situations within their NDIS plans due to the loss of essential paperwork and lack of responsiveness from the NDIS.
The NDIS is failing to conduct timely reviews to accommodate participants' changing needs, leaving service providers carrying debt on behalf of the NDIS.

Service providers are burdened with significant losses due to the NDIS's failure to conduct timely reviews and accommodate changing participant needs. This places an unfair burden on service providers, who should not be responsible for carrying such losses.
Improving NDIS Efficiency: Urging reforms to enhance NDIS effectiveness in meeting disability needs while managing costs responsibly.
Advocating for Vulnerable Individuals: Protecting the rights and welfare of NDIS-dependent vulnerable individuals, stressing the need for a sustainable support system.
Demanding Government Action: Urging immediate government intervention to address NDIS shortcomings, implement reforms, and secure the scheme's long-term success.

We therefore ask the House to address critical concerns surrounding NDIS. Participants are experiencing significant disruptions in care during crises due to administrative inefficiencies and the NDIS's sluggish responsiveness, necessitating immediate measures to streamline paperwork processes and enhance responsiveness. Delayed reviews are leaving service providers burdened with substantial debt, undermining both their financial stability and participants' access to necessary support. Service providers should not bear the financial consequences of the NDIS's shortcomings, necessitating immediate action to relieve their unsustainable losses and hold the NDIS accountable.
from 77 citizens (Petition No. EN6084)
Migration

Australia is a signatory to the United Nations Conventions on the Rights of the Child (CRC), ICCPR, ICESCR, International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers, The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD) amongst others and through these conventions agree to respect the right to family and recognize a child's right to grow up in a family environment. The Australian law (Family Law Act under section 60B(2)(b)) recognizes that children have a right to spend time regularly with and communicate regularly with their parents and grandparents as people significant to their care, welfare and development. The government recognizes the importance of relationships with grandparents and advocates the role of grandparents in the lives of children and grandchildren. But naturalised citizens and residents are discriminated against, and their naturally recognized right to spend time with their parents and grandparents is being denied by: a. a very unreasonable timeline for processing the parent visas (i.e. 12 to 29 years) with costs going up to AUD48,365; and b. introducing the family balance test as a prerequisite for processing parent visas.

We therefore ask the House to 1. reduce the waiting timelines for parent visas to a reasonably acceptable 3-6 months and increase parent visa quotas. 2. Repeal the 'family balance test' requirements in these visas to allow all residents and citizens the right to association with their parents and grandparents. In the interest of justice and equality.
from 1,059 citizens (Petition No. EN6085)
Legal Aid

There are many children who are caught up in the middle of nasty child custody battles resulting in some children being alienated from a parent/caregiver or living in abusive homes because a paren/caregiver believes they have the right to maintain sole custody.
Children have the right to a healthy, positive relationship with their parents or to be protected if necessary, we as the parent/caregiver have an obligation to meet the rights of our children.

With approximately three percent of family law matters ending up at trial, Legal Aid does not offer financial aid which results in many parents/caregivers being unable to afford to pay for a lawyer to represent them so they can meet their obligations to their children.

Sometimes lawyers charge as little as $2000 to start the process but this is unaffordable for some people when they are also paying to support themselves and pay child support. There will also be further payments required that will total thousands of dollars before a matter is finalised.
We therefore ask the House to extend Legal Aid funding to assist with child custody/visitation matters including funding for parenting programs and supervised visits.

We ask for this to be means tested based on what the applicants financial situation is and not their gross income with the understanding this is to assist those who find it impossible to cover the legal expenses associated with child custody/access arrangements.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN6086)
Renewable Energy

During the public education sessions in the South West of WA, a notable lack of transparency regarding the benefits and environmental impacts was demonstrated. After attending a very poorly organised event, it is unclear which companies are involved, if any studies have been done on the whale populations and other marine life, when the project will become carbon neutral, how our energy prices will be affected, where the finance is coming from, how many subsidies will be received, how environmental and human health will be impacted, and the overall cost to the tax payer. Due to this the public have made it clear that they do not want for this project to go ahead, and that specifically more environmentally friendly options be explored.
We therefore ask the House to halt the construction of the windfarm in Geographe Bay.
from 263 citizens (Petition No. EN6087)
Personal Information and Privacy
Any law or rules made for digital ID to be Abandoned and laws put in so a digital ID will never be allowed to happen.
We therefore ask the House to remove the vote for digital ID by politicians and a referendum put in place so that taxpayers can decide on a digital ID.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN6088)
Personal Information and Privacy

In Australia, there is no constitutional right to privacy. While the Privacy Act 1988, and the Surveillance Devices Act 2004 & 2007 serve as important pieces of legislation, they have not been adequately updated to reflect important technological advances, such as the advent of the Internet. Furthermore, the extremely antiquated Telecommunications Act (Interception and Access) (TIA) 1979 exposed Australians to draconian interception of their data and private communications from Intelligence Services and the Police in 2014 without so much as a given warrant or notice, even if their private messages could be deleted and/or altered. These laws have not kept pace with advancements of the 21st century, and put Australia's most vulnerable at risk. These people include Women and Children, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, people with disabilities and the poor—but also the population at large. It further compromises everyone from victims of Coercive Control, Violence, and Bullying from managers at work and from landlords from getting the Legal Protection they need in order to protect themselves. Privacy is a fundamental aspect of human dignity, and it is also a human right. As a ratified member of the United Nations, Australia upholds the values of the UN Charter of Human Rights. Therefore, Australia's privacy laws should be revisited to reflect human rights in the modern world, as it is undemocratic to deny people their freedom and safety by lawfully enabling their exposure to control by surveillance by those more powerful.
We therefore ask the House to review legislation.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN6090)

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024

p.span: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024

We urgently petition against the proposed legislation (Migration Amendment (Removals and Other Measures) Bill 2024) affecting Iranian visa applicants. The bill gives excessive discretion to the Minister, potentially excluding deserving Iranians who comply with visa conditions and aim to contribute positively to Australian society. This bill threatens the entry of skilled, student, and tourist visa seekers, contradicting principles of fairness and equality.

We therefore ask the House to reject this bill. This bill would perpetuate discrimination based on nationality and undermine Australia's values of inclusivity and opportunity. We call for a transparent and fair approach to visa legislation that welcomes individuals from diverse backgrounds. We are ready to engage in constructive dialogue to find a solution that upholds the integrity of the visa system while fostering inclusivity.
from 4,543 citizens (Petition No. EN6091)
Skilled Migration
Dear;

Australian government has granted 476 visa to Engineers to land in Australia. But after landing in Australia and applying for multiple job related to engineers. We engineers are stuck in between our PR problem and our job requirement as every employer is demanding for long term commitment. We are unable to get security clearance due to our Temporary residency.
We all got same question in our interview that Sorry: you do not have PR and we are unable to hire you and we have to do ODD jobs.
We therefore ask the House to discuss this issue.
from 65 citizens (Petition No. EN6093)
Animal Welfare
Dog are part of the families and should be considered as that, it's not fair to leave them at home because we can't have a breakfast, buy groceries or even put fuel because they can't enter.
The food is not made on the floor and kitchens are far from the tables.
Also, dog can't transmit diseases to humans otherwise the footpath would be the worst place ever for kids..
We therefore ask the House to allow dogs, with due limitations, if the shop owner decides to allow them, to let the dogs enter anywhere.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6094)
Economy
Subject: Petition for a 31.87% Expenditure Cap Over 6 Years and Gas/Electricity Bill Tax Rebate
Dear Members of the Australian House of Representatives,

We, the undersigned, respectfully petition for the implementation of a 31.87% expenditure cap over the next six years, starting from 2030. This measure is crucial to ensure fiscal discipline, efficiency in government spending, and long-term economic stability.

Furthermore, we advocate for the introduction of a 10% gas and electricity bill income tax rebate, indexed to 75% inflation and 25% productivity rate. This rebate would provide essential relief to Australian households grappling with high energy costs, particularly benefiting lower and middle-income families. Additionally, it would incentivize energy efficiency and productivity enhancements, contributing to a more sustainable future for all.

The proposed rebate's structure includes clear scope, percentage, indexation, and administration mechanisms to ensure effectiveness and prevent misuse. Transparent reporting, regular evaluation, and adjustment procedures will be vital for monitoring the program's impact and efficiency.
We believe these initiatives are crucial for Australia's economic resilience and the well-being of its citizens. We urge your support for these measures to secure a better future for all Australians.
We therefore ask the House to Have consideration for Honorable Members to observe this Petition and to hopefuly act upon it
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6095)
Personal Information and Privacy
Digital ID rejects democracy, induces totalitarianism and takes away God given freedoms.
We therefore ask the House to reject all submissions regarding any digital ID bills. Australia does not want to be dependent on or controlled by the government.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN6097)
Renewable Energy

We are unsatisfied with the consultation process and the lack of research backing the use of wind turbines. The danger to the environment and endangered species is becoming increasingly evident, yet there appears to be very little if any benefits.

We therefore ask the House to stop all Offshore Wind Turbine Proposals and Plans for good. Wind Turbines are known historically to cause direct injury, displacement and impediment of migratory paths of Blue Whales, Pygmy Blue Whales, Southern Right Whale and Humpback protected under the EPBC Act 1999. This is sanctioned violations of International Treaties and our own Federal Laws."
from 1,440 citizens (Petition No. EN6098)
Aviation Industry

The Boeing 737 MAX jets have a concerning history marred by catastrophic crashes, notably Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 and Lion Air Flight 610, resulting in tragic loss of all on board. Recent incidents, including a reported mid-flight nosedive from Auckland to Sydney and a panel detachment over Portland, Oregon, underscore the urgency of addressing safety issues.
There have been too many deaths and close calls to dub this an unfortunate coincidence.
Boeing is knowingly putting the lives of its passengers at risk—with all cases involving technical and/or design flaws—how is this plane allowed to fly?
It's imperative to prioritise passenger safety and take decisive action to mitigate further risks associated with these aircraft.

We therefore ask the House to ground all Boeing 737 MAX jets until comprehensive and independent safety assessments are conducted, and any necessary modifications are made to ENSURE the airworthiness of these aircrafts.
The safety of passengers and crew must always be the priority, and it is imperative that decisive action is taken to prevent any further tragedies.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6099)
Australian Constitution
1. Majority of Australians support our current Monarchist system.
2. The Albanese Government has NO mandate to change our system of Government.
3. The Albanese Government appointed a Minister for the Republic.
4. Governor Generals should be appointed that support a Monarchist system that they represent and are NOT Republicans.

We therefore ask the House to acknowledge we have a King as head of state and NO actions should be taken that disrespect the voice of the majority of Australians wanting to maintain that system. That the Prime Minister dismiss the created position of Minister for a Republic and only appoint Governor Generals that support the present system and not be Republicans. That the Government not take subversive actions that assist to undermine the current system with His Majesty King Charles 111 as the Head of State.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN6100)
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Five year old children should not be exposed to detailed sex information, since they are not mentally developed enough to cope with it.
We therefore ask the House to of Representatives to Exit Australia from the W.H.O. and U.N. because they are demanding that School Teachers must provide "Comprehensive Sex Education",
starting with 5 year old children.
from 60 citizens (Petition No. EN6101)
Medicare

Australia's mental health landscape is in dire need of immediate attention and comprehensive support measures. One crucial aspect that requires urgent reform is the provision of psychological services through Medicare. Currently, the limited number of subsidized sessions available under Medicare does not adequately cater to individuals grappling with complex mental health conditions.

We therefore ask the House to increase the Medicare rebate for psychology sessions to a minimum of 20 sessions per year for individuals with complex mental health issues. This adjustment is crucial in ensuring that those who are most vulnerable and in need of ongoing support have access to the necessary resources without facing financial hardship.
from 311 citizens (Petition No. EN6102)
International Relations: Australia and Israel
Last year Israel came under attack from an enemy with no regard for human lives or values.
The horrific and calculated attacks of October 7th shocked the rules based societies of the world and threaten the very existence of Israel.
The attacks were a violation of international law and conducted without respect for our shared democratic and human values.

The enemy Israel faces does not respect human rights, does not respect the role of women in society or the rights of the LGBTIQA+ community. Israels enemy does not uphold shared values of the world community such as climate action or racial inclusivity.
The attacks on Israel are not only the concern of Israel but should be the concern of all governments and peoples.
We therefore ask the House to support our ally Israel in their justified acts of defence in this critical time
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN6103)
Boomerang Throwing
Boomerang Throwing has its roots in Australian Indigenous history and culture and is competed internationally amongst over 18 countries around the world.
Australia has it very own National Boomerang Throwing team, that has been competing Internationally since 1981.
Currently the Australian Government does not recognise the sport of Boomerang Throwing and there is a lack of awareness amongst First Nation and Australian citizens.
We therefore ask the House to have the Sport of Boomerang Throwing recognised by our Australian government and the Australian Sports commission as an official Sport in Australia.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN6104)
International Relations: Australia and Israel
Israel is blatantly and unapologetically killing civilians, including women, children, medical staff, journalists and aid workers and an unprecedented level.
This is done under the guise of self defence.
This is done under the guise of freeing hostages.
Neither of these are true.
Israel wants land. Israel wants Gaza. Israel wants to remove Palestinians from the face of the earth.
This is genocide.
We therefore ask the House to expel the Israeli ambassador, to send a clear and firm message that we as Australians, do not except their brutal behavior.
from 160 citizens (Petition No. EN6105)
Middle East
Reasons for the Petition:

The ongoing violence and oppression against Palestinians by the Israeli government violate fundamental human rights principles. The disproportionate use of force, illegal settlements, and blockade of Gaza have resulted in immense suffering and loss of life. Our nation should not support regimes engaged in such violations.
Action Requested:
We urge the Prime Minister to take a principled stand against the Israeli government's actions by severing diplomatic ties, ending military support, and condemning human rights abuses in Palestine.
We therefore ask the House to do the following
1. Cutting Diplomatic Ties: Ceasing all diplomatic relations with the Israeli government.
2. Expelling Israeli Ambassador: Removing the Israeli Ambassador from our country.
3. Ceasing All Military Exports: Ending all exports of military equipment, including parts of F35s, to Israel.
4. Ending Contracts with Elbit Systems: Terminating the 900k contract with Elbit Systems, a company implicated in human rights violations against Palestinians.
5. Condemning Disproportionate Deaths: Condemning the disproportionate deaths of up to 40,000 Palestinians at the hands of the Israeli government.
6. Supporting South Africa's Case: Supporting South Africa's case proving a genocide of Palestinians by the Israeli government.
from 16,391 citizens (Petition No. EN6106)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

The NDIS should not be managed by political parties, the NDIS should have equal board members of active NDIS Participants. The NDIS has spent the last 10yrs being used as hammer to hit disabled people with. Lets stop politicians using the scheme as a way to get votes with out true understanding of what living with a disability is really like.
Change your language- the language used around the NDIS is used to deter any participants from understanding, using and working with the scheme.
We therefore ask the House to review who is actually decision making within the NDIS, ensuring that the all committee members by 50% active participants of the NDIS.
Make the Scheme unaccessible to political parties as a toll for votes. Make it an Independent Scheme allowing for alternate management styles the are more suited to todays changing needs.
Change the name of the NDIS to the National Disability inclusion Scheme, removing the word insurance.
Have the Scheme Legislation and NDIS policies procedures and guidelines written in common english.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN6107)
Nuclear Energy
The antipodeans Sir Ernest Rutherford "father of nuclear physics" and Sir Mark Oliphant, "Opposer of the fission bomb" were the first experimental demonstrators of nuclear fusion.
Should then the Australian Government and the Federal Opposition not work to get a fusion industry developed in Australia and bring it back home?
New Zealand is, so why not Australia?

We therefore ask the House to swiftly consider implementing research and developing fusion power in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution not only addresses future climate concerns and enhances energy security, but also holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation, involving experts and the public, to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing a cleaner, more resilient energy landscape for our nation.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6108)
Nuclear Energy

To get Australians the benefits of Australian government funding of businesses and their retention of investment and technology development in the international fusion energy industry on Australian shores. getting licencing of and the development of Fusion energy in Australia and the building of demonstration fusion power plants to show commercial viability so Australia can participate in this international growth industry.

We therefore ask the House to swiftly consider funding and implementing research and development into fusion power in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution not only addresses future climate concerns and enhances energy security, but also holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation, involving experts and the public, to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing a cleaner, more resilient energy landscape for our nation.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6109)
Nuclear Energy
Authorities can grant licenses for fusion, which is not explicitly covered by the Nuclear Act or the ARPANSA definition. As ARPANSA defines nuclear as fission—no mention of Fusion.
A fission (Nuclear) reactor without fissile fuel is a building.
A fusion reactor without fissile fuel is a fusion reactor building

In the IAEA fusion conference report in 2023, the IAEA postulated that all International nuclear (Fission) Laws like the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty do not consider fusion, so it seems it can be built in Australia now.
Fusion commercial power generation is expected to be demonstrated in 2028 by Helion and commercial in 2030.
We therefore ask the House to supply funding for the development of fusion power plants and develop a fusion industry in Australia and work with New Zealand on this matter.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6110)
Medical Workforce: Governance
Australian doctors are not represented by a union.
AHPHRA & the Medical Boards are not held accountable for any decisions made even without an investigation.
A number of Australian doctors have committed suicide after being accused of wrongdoing without evidence by AHPRA & the Medical Boards.
AHPRA has covered up instances of wrongdoing to patients and doctors.
We therefore ask the House to create an independent committee made up of clinically active health professionals to oversee the decisions of AHPRA & the Medical Boards.
from 324 citizens (Petition No. EN6113)
Personal Information and Privacy

The Digital Identity Bill 2024 poses a clear and imminent threat to the personal digital security of ALL Australian Citizens, and is a grievous infringement on the Civil Rights of freedom loving Australians—past, present and FUTURE. A centralised Government monitored agency, that compiles a comprehensive dossier of its citizens, and shares such information with other FEDERAL and STATE GOVERNMENT agencies, along with PRIVATE CORPORATIONS and COMPANIES such as Social Media outlets, is open to an abuse of Government power and authority, and the complete eradication of the principles of our Democracy.

We therefore ask the House to Immediately, and forthwith repeal the 'Digital Identity Bill 2024', along with all and subsequent amendments. We the undersigned, REJECT ALL authority of this, and any future Australian Federal Government, to oversee and manage our digital information in any manner that infringes on our Civil and Human Rights for the Freedom to choose how we use, and how we choose to manage our individual digital footprint and information.
from 1,116 citizens (Petition No. EN6115)
Skilled Migration

As a software engineer with over four years of dedicated service in Australia, I applied for the 186TRT visa. Until a few months ago, the DHA was prioritizing offshore applicants over onshore due to market needs which wasn't fair to us, but I was encouraged by the progress in processing all applications. However, recent ministerial direction 105 supporting regional businesses resulted in the halt of processing metro applicants including us, who have contributed to the economy and filled skill shortages since the challenging times of COVID without visiting loving ones in pandemic. We are not the cause of housing crisis. It's disheartening to see our applications deprioritized, especially when we've been lawfully residing in Australia for years, paying taxes and our super, and supporting the community. Some of us may not be eligible or have the trust to apply another visa and turn back if things won't go as expected. The eligibility or nature of businesses can change until a decision is made which is possible given the current global processing timeline. Many of us have specialized skills due to our commitment and experience, contributing significantly to Australia. It's crucial to receive a decision promptly. Waiting indefinitely jeopardizes our future, self-confidence, and negotiating power in this tough economic situation, reducing productivity and undermining the government's goal of ending the cycle of temporary residency and dependency on employers.
We therefore ask the House to prioritise onshore employer sponsored temporary resident transition visa applicants
from 59 citizens (Petition No. EN6116)
Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme

The new generation Drospirenone progesterone-only pill, Slinda, has been recommended for women who cannot take estrogen, have a history of thrombosis, are considered 'overweight' and those who smoke. This medication is frequently prescribed as a treatment for women with chronic pelvic pain conditions such as Endometriosis, Adenomyosis and PCOS. However, this medication is up to seven times more expensive than other contraceptive pills. This medicine has been life-saving for women who experience chronic pelvic pain—drastically improving their quality of life and ability to function in society.
We therefore ask the House to consider action to add this medication, 'Slinda', to the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6117)
Child Abuse

I am a survivor, as is someone very dear to me. We are among the countless victims of child sexual abuse, a crime so heinous it's hard to comprehend. The pain we've endured is unimaginable, and we know there are many more out there suffering in silence. It's time for our justice system to reflect the severity of these crimes.

Child sex offenders often receive lenient sentences that do not match the gravity of their actions. According to RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network), only 5 out of every 1,000 perpetrators will end up in prison. This lack of severe punishment not only fails to deter potential offenders but also adds insult to injury for victims who have bravely come forward.
We propose two changes: Firstly, significantly increase jail time for convicted child sex offenders. Secondly, open a national debate on legalising the death penalty for such crimes.

These measures may seem drastic but consider this—according to the U.S Department of Justice's National Sex Offender Public Website (NSOPW), approximately 60% of perpetrators are known to the child but are not family members; friends, babysitters or neighbours—people children should be able to trust implicitly.

Our children deserve better protection from these predators who lurk within our communities disguised as trustworthy individuals. Let us ensure that they face punishments befitting their monstrous acts.
We therefore ask the House to increase penalties for child sex offenders and consider legalising the death penalty.
from 84 citizens (Petition No. EN6118)
Migration
According to recent ABS data, Australia took in 784,000 migrants in just 12 months.

This is the highest intake of migrants Australia has ever seen, and it comes at a time when rental vacancy rates are as low as 0.7%, when homeless is going up as high as 50%, and housing is at its most unaffordable ever.
Not only that, but roads are getting busier, hospital wait times are getting longer, public transport is cramped and delayed, and police numbers are dwindling.
Worse still, immigration is actually tracking higher than last year. For reference, more people moved to Australia in the January this year, than the entire year of 1993.

This is a social and economic disaster waiting to happen, and it's putting Australia on a path towards chaos. Australian living standards are plummeting, and our young and most vulnerable are being forever locked out of the housing market.
But the problem can be fixed.
We therefore ask the House to pause immigration for at least two years, letting housing, infrastructure, public services, wages and social cohesion catch up.
Then, we can recalibrate our vision, and put Australia on a better path forward.
A path where young people can afford a home and start a family, where cities are more liveable, and our most vulnerable can put a roof over their head.
That is a vision of Australia many people will want to work towards.
from 426 citizens (Petition No. EN6119)
Telecommunications

The pending shutdown of the 3G network poses significant challenges and risks to Australian citizens. This outdated infrastructure continues to serve vital purposes, especially in rural and remote areas where access to 4G or 5G networks is limited or non-existent. Discontinuing 3G would exacerbate the digital divide, impact businesses and emergency services, force unnecessary upgrades for consumers, and disrupt voice traffic that relies on 3G networks.

We therefore ask the House to take immediate action to permanently suspend the pending 3G shutdown. This action would ensure continued access to essential services, support businesses in adapting to modern communication needs, safeguard public safety, preserve consumer choice, and mitigate environmental impacts related to premature device obsolescence.

The House of Representatives has the authority to address this issue at a national level, ensuring a coordinated and equitable approach that considers the diverse needs of all Australians. We urge the House to prioritize the well-being and connectivity of its citizens by halting the 3G shutdown and exploring sustainable solutions that align with the principles of accessibility, affordability, and inclusivity.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN6120)
Climate Change
Australian net zero targets will not make a quantifiable difference to the environment on our planet and will instead put unnecessary strain on the citizens of Australia.

We therefore ask the House to scrap net zero targets and reconsider the approach to environmental sustainability. The efficacy of the targets is questionable due to the likes of China and India not participating in net zero, and therefore offsetting any minute difference Australia will make. The push for electric vehicles is also not viable due to the lack of available infrastructure, the size and make-up of Australia, and will disrupte the Australian way of life. Not only that, but the damage to the environment considering the lifecycle of an electric car vs a modern diesel SUV should be explored so that decisions are being made with quantative data.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN6121)
International Relations: Australia and Israel

The Australian government is refusing to disclose information regarding relations between Australia and Israel. Australian taxpayers have a right to know how our democratically elected Government is involved and/ or complicit with Israel's military operations in Gaza and Palestinian territories. As such, a Freedom of Information (FOI) request for a copy of the "Memorandum of Understanding" (MOU) signed between Australia and Israel in 2017 is put forward.

We therefore ask the House to release a copy of the MOU signed between Australia and Israel in 2017, to ensure transparency between the government and Australian taxpayers. Further, we request a document outlining costs (per item) associated with the MOU that have used Australian taxpayer's money in part or in full.
from 113 citizens (Petition No. EN6122)
Telecommunications

The roll out of 5G microwave radiation infrastructure continues across Victoria despite serious community concerns about the risk to public health especially to workers subject to irradiation from 5G. There are many concerns about the link between 5G and increased cancer risk. In addition, there has been proven inadequate community consultation in Orbost or Marlo about the roll out.

We therefore ask the House to call upon the Government to comply with OHS legislation and conduct a full and proper risk assessment of 5G regarding its risk to the health and safety of workers on the infrastructure and in its vicinity whether in buildings or those working on the ground and we request a full moratorium on 5G roll out until the long-term impacts and effects of 5G and 6G are known.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN6123)

subdebateinfo.title: E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products: Medicinal Cannabis

p.span: E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products: Medicinal Cannabis

We, the undersigned, highlight the restricted access to reusable cannabis vaping devices, sold exclusively in pharmacies, impacting users of both medicinal and non-medicinal cannabis across Australia. With increased public discourse surrounding states and territories following the Australian Capital Territory's decriminalise cannabis, the issue of accessibility is a matter of public health, safety and harm reduction.
We therefore ask the House to these devices like other Class IIA, III & IV medical devices, allowing them to be sold in retail settings, ensuring they meet strict medical and manufacturing standards.

Currently, reusable cannabis vaping devices are classified similarly to medical devices, with restricted sale to pharmacies. This limitation affects a growing number of Australians who rely on cannabis for health and well-being, making device access cumbersome and restrictive. By aligning these devices with medical device regulations, they would still adhere to rigorous safety and quality standards, mirroring the controls on similar healthcare products. This change would facilitate better access, allowing responsible use and ensuring safety through regulated manufacturing standards. Countries with similar regulatory adjustments have seen improved public health outcomes, consumer safety, and access to these devices.

To support the health and rights of cannabis users, we request the House to consider the regulation change, making reusable cannabis vaping devices more accessible in retail environments, while maintaining the necessary safety and quality standards.

We trust the Parliament will recognize the significance of this issue and act promptly to revise the regulations, enhancing accessibility and ensuring the well-being of Australians relying on these devices.
from 2,189 citizens (Petition No. EN6127)
National Security
This petition is to make sure the Australian government and people see Taliban as a threat and recognise them as a terrorist organisation that they are.

We therefore ask the House to consider Taliban as a terrorist organization that they are. There are reports that the Afghanistan has become a terrors haven for terrorist groups such as the Taliban, ISIS and other groups.
from 70 citizens (Petition No. EN6128)
Pancreatic Cancer

Request for Lynparza to be added to the PBS for Pancreatic Cancer with BRCA mutation. It is currently available on the PBS for some cancers including certain Ovarian cancers, advanced Breast Cancer (with BRCA mutation), Fallopian tube cancer, primary Peritoneal cancer. The current cost of Lynparza is approximately $20,000 per month and is well outside what the everyday person can afford. The added stress of being told about this drug and that it may help, is horribly unfair to people (and their families) who are already under enormous stress, when they find out the cost is way out of reach but is available for other cancer sufferers. All treatment options should be available to all Australians at a cost that they can afford.

We therefore ask the House to discuss and put forward this request as a matter of urgency to help the many Australians that are currently suffering this horrible form of cancer to give them a chance at saving or extending their life at a cost that doesn't put added stress on them or their loved ones.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN6130)
Great Artesian Basin

The citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House the immediate need to stop an application by Glencore to pump their carbon emissions into the pristine Great Artesian Basin (GAB) and to prevent any future such applications.
Pristine water in the GAB underpins the viability of inland Australia. Hundreds of communities, industries, and tourism, all supporting $13 billion each year rely on this natural resource.
Without immediate intervention the GAB is at dire risk from Glencore's plan.
We therefore ask the House to immediately protect the GAB from any injection of carbon emissions by putting in place regulation prohibiting Carbon Capture and Storage in the GAB.
from 307 citizens (Petition No. EN6134)
Middle East
Wars in Middle East destroyed ordinary people lives in Israel as well as Gaza
We therefore ask the House to arrange for Israelites to take refuge in Australia
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN6136)
Visa Refusal or Cancellation

The current law allows the Minister for Immigration to cancel the visa of anyone failing the character test, regardless of how long they've lived here. In 2019 alone, over 800 people were deported under this law (source: Department of Home Affairs). Many were sent back to countries where they had no existing family or support networks.
We believe that it's time we reassess this policy and consider its human impact.
We urge our government officials not only to reconsider my brother's case but also review these laws that displace long-term residents from their homes and families.
We therefore ask the House to reconsider these pending cases and stop the harsh laws against long-term Australian residents under the 501.
from 237 citizens (Petition No. EN6138)
Australian Society

Australia is renowned for its rich tapestry of cultures, embodying diversity across all walks of life. As a multicultural nation, our strength lies in our collective differences and the harmonious blend of traditions and diversity that each community brings. However, while there are many initiatives that celebrate individual cultures, there remains a significant opportunity for a unifying celebration that encompasses all Australians, regardless of their cultural background.
We propose that the National Day of Unity be celebrated annually, with nationwide events, cultural performances, community gatherings, and educational programs in schools and public institutions.
We therefore ask the House to establish of a National Day of Unity in Australia
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN6139)

subdebateinfo.title: Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons

p.span: Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons

The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) was adopted by 122 countries of the United Nations on 7 July 2017. It entered into force on 22 January 2021. The TPNW is the first globally applicable multilateral agreement to comprehensively prohibit nuclear weapons .. Nuclear disarmament is a cause that all countries must embrace. A single nuclear weapon could destroy a city. Civilians would make up most of the casualties and responders would be unable to work in devastated, radioactively contaminated areas. No country could stop the radioactive fallout that would transcend national borders if these weapons are ever used again. No country is immune to the climate disruption, agricultural and economic collapse, mass human displacement and famine that would inevitably follow even a 'limited' nuclear war. Nuclear weapons serve no legitimate military or strategic purpose and, given their indiscriminate nature, cannot be used in conformity with international law. By ratifying the TPNW, Australia can help strengthen the global norm against the possession and use of nuclear weapons and make an important contribution to their total elimination.
We therefore ask the House to commit to the ratification of the TPNW at the earliest opportunity.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. PN0606)
Queensland Air Museum

In 2019, along with other heritage organisations, QAM submitted an Expression of Interest to Defence to be allocated an F/A-18 'Classic' Hornet. We recently became aware that 8 aircraft have been delivered to 7 other heritage organisations, with the remaining 41 aircraft destined for destruction. Despite repeated requests to the Minister, we remain unaware of the reasons why Australia's largest air museum has not been allocated a Hornet, why Queensland was the only state with an air museum to be denied an allocation, why we were not advised of the decision at the time. The Queensland Air Museum (QAM), located in Caloundra, is Australia's largest aviation museum and a major tourist attraction. It is home to a diverse collection of over 80 historic military and civilian aircraft, a large display of aero engines, an extensive range of rare Australian aviation artifacts. Sustained by a workforce of 150 volunteers who participate in a wide range of activities from museum management and administration to complex aircraft restoration and maintenance, the museum is an important community, tourism and educational venue.

We ask the House of Representatives to request the Minister for Defence to direct his Department to allocate one of the remaining F/A-18 'Classic' Hornet aircraft scheduled for destruction to the Queensland Air Museum for restoration, preservation and display.
from 1,318 citizens (Petition No. PN0608)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present 26 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
Rail Infrastructure
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition EN5653 on subsidies allocated to road transport and rail infrastructure. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is investing over $35 billion in rail infrastructure projects over the ten-years from 2023-24, including in Inland Rail, Sydney Metro—Western Sydney Airpo1t, Logan and Gold Coast Faster Rail, Suburban Rail Loop East, Direct Sunshine Coast Rail Line, Metronet, Melbourne Airport Rail Link and Canberra Light Rail. The Government is also making complementary rail infrastructure investments in the Moorebank and Beveridge intermodal precincts via the National Intermodal Corporation.

On 14 November 2023, I released the Infrastructure Policy Statement which sets out three strategic themes that will guide future Government investment decisions: Productivity and Resilience, Liveability and Sustainability. Future investments will have a range of significant economic, social and environmental objectives including ensuring they contribute to Australia's future sustainability and net zero ambitions.

The Government has also set ambitious targets for emissions reduction and strong action will be required across all transp01t modes. Work to deliver these targets for transport will be undertaken in a planned and coordinated way to help ensure we can take up economic and productivity oppo1tunities, while carefully managing the transition to new energy sources for the whole of our transport sector.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Whistleblower Protection
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 February 2024 regarding petition EN5691, which asked the House to strengthen protections for whistleblowers. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.
The Albanese Government is committed to ensuring that Australia has effective frameworks to protect whistleblowers.

The Public Interest Disclosure Act 2013 (PID Act) is an important element of the Commonwealth's integrity and transparency framework. The PID Act enables public officials to disclose suspected wrongdoing by another public official or by an Australian Government agency and requires disclosures to be properly investigated and dealt with.

It also provides those public officials with the assurance that, if they make their disclosure in accordance with the requirements of the PID Act, they will be protected from reprisal and immune from administrative, criminal and civil liability, including absolute privilege in proceedings for defamation.
The Government is delivering on its commitment to strengthen protections for public sector whistleblowers through staged reform of the public sector whistleblowing framework.

On 1 July 2023, priority amendments to the PID Act came into effect, which ensured immediate improvements to the public sector whistleblower scheme were in place for the commencement of the National Anti-Corruption Commission. These reforms implemented 21 of the 33 recommendations from the 2016 Review of the PID Act by Mr Philip Moss AM as well as recommendations from other parliamentary committee reports. Key measures in the legislation strengthened protections for disclosers and witnesses, focused the framework on integrity-related wrongdoing, made the framework easier to administer, and enhanced oversight of the framework by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.

In late 2023, the Government released a consultation paper on a second stage of reforms to ensure the framework remains fit for purpose and accessible for public officials to report wrongdoing. The second stage of reforms will consider the remaining recommendations of the Moss Review and other relevant reports and reviews, as well as stakeholder views expressed in the public consultation. The second stage of reforms is an opportunity to further improve the public sector whistleblowing framework by considering how to address the underlying complexity of the PID Act and what steps can be taken to provide effective and accessible protections to public sector whistleblowers.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair
In response to petition number EN5749, please relay to the signees of the petition that their concerns are unfounded.

A Digital ID is simply an online method of confirming your ID that does not require physical documents once it's set up. It works by verifying your existing ID documents such as a passport or driver license against the official record held by government.

The purpose of a Digital ID is to reduce the amount of information that businesses and government needs to hold that can be at risk of data theft. By using a Digital ID, people can avoid repeatedly sharing copies of their ID documents and all the information they hold.

The Digital ID Bill 2024 puts in place strong privacy and security safeguards to protect individuals who choose to create and use a Digital ID will an accredited Digital ID provider. Profiling and surveillance is specifically prohibited in the Bill. Digital ID cannot be used to track spending, online activity, or restrict participation in the community. Digital ID will not be combined with Central Bank Digital Currencies.

The Digital ID Bill ensures that the choice to create and use a Digital ID to access Commonwealth government services is voluntary for individuals. There can be no exemptions to this requirement and there will always be alternative ways to access Commonwealth government services for individuals, as there are now. Under the Bill, the ACCC can grant exemptions for businesses, however this is expected to be in limited circumstances such as where the business operates solely online.
We thank the signees for their engagement with Digital ID and hope this information provides assurance. You can also find out more at www.digitalidentity.gov.au
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Gallagher
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair
In response to petition number EN5751, please relay to the signees of the petition that their concerns are unfounded.
There are no similarities between Australia's Digital ID System and social credit systems.

A Digital ID is simply an online method of confirming your ID that does not require physical documents once it's set up. It works by verifying your existing ID documents such as a passport or driver license against the official record held by government.

The purpose of a Digital ID is to reduce the amount of information that businesses and government needs to hold that can be at risk of data theft. By using a Digital ID, people can avoid repeatedly sharing copies of their ID documents and all the information they hold.

The Digital ID Bill 2024 puts in place strong privacy and security safeguards to protect individuals who choose to create and use a Digital ID will an accredited Digital ID provider. Profiling and surveillance is specifically prohibited in the Bill. Digital ID cannot be used to track spending, online activity, or restrict participation in the community.

The Digital ID Bill ensures that the choice to create and use a Digital ID to access Commonwealth government services is voluntary for individuals. There can be no exemptions to this requirement and there will always be alternative ways to access Commonwealth government services for individuals, as there are now.
We thank the signees for their engagement with Digital ID and hope this information provides assurance. You can also find out more at www.digitalidentity.gov.au
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Gallagher
Middle East
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 February 2024 to the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon Richard Marles MP, regarding petition EN5771, Preventing Australian citizens from serving in the Israel Defence Fotces (JDF). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the subject matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
The Government cautions all Australians who seek to serve with the armed forces of a foreign country to carefully consider their legal obligations.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning a petition (EN5784) recently presented in the House concerning the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) supervisory cost recovery levy.

The Government acknowledges the impact of regulatory costs on businesses, including financial advice businesses, and the need for fairness in the implementation of ASIC's Industry Funding Model (IFM).

The IFM is established on the principle that those who create the need for a regulatory activity or benefit from it should bear the associated costs, rather than burdening general taxpayers. The Government has carefully reviewed ASIC's IFM and the final report of the review, which I released on 26 June 2023, re-emphasised this important principle.

As the petition notes, licensees that provide personal advice to retail clients were provided temporary support during the pandemic via a reduction in their levies in relation to the 2020-21 and 2021-22 financial years. However, this was not intended to be permanent given the principle outlined above. It would also raise concerns about fairness to other sub- sectors that contribute to ASIC funding under the IFM. The 2022-23 graduated levy component for personal advice licensees (sometimes referred to as the 'per advisor levy') reflects the amount required to recover relevant costs in 2022-23, as set out in ASIC's Cost Recovery Implementation Statement. The size of its apparent increase over previous years reflects that in the relief years those costs were not recovered from that sub-sector in full.

I note the petitioners' concern that fees for advisers appear to be increasing while fees for licensees 'remain at $1,500', however, this is not how the IFM operates. As a matter of law, ASIC's supervisory cost recovery levies for the financial advice sector are imposed entirely on licensees, not on individual advisers. Like many other sub-sectors, the ASIC IFM levy for licensees that provide personal advice is scaled based on the size of the entity. This ensures there is fairness in how the levy applies across different licensees. For licensees that provide personal advice on relevant financial products to retail clients, the levy is a minimum of $1,500 plus a variable amount—the graduated levy component—per registered adviser. The number of advisers is used here as the proxy for the size of the licensee. Increasing the minimum levy component would make the levy less reflective of licensee size; larger licensees would pay relatively less, while smaller licensees would pay relatively more.

Once a licensee's levy is calculated, it is up to the individual licensee how it pays the levy, including what component (if any) it requires its advisers to pay. Whether or how a licensee passes on the levy to its authorised representatives is a matter for their contractual relationship; the Government has no expectation that the licensee will pay the minimum levy component while the adviser pays the remainder.

The IFM review recommended considering certain sub-sector definitions, entity metrics, and levy formulas to ensure they remain appropriate for the calculation of the levies. The Government intends to consult on these changes in due course and I encourage affected financial advisers to participate in that consultation process.

The Government has a comprehensive package to ensure Australians have access to quality and affordable financial advice when they need it most. On 7 December 2023 I announced the Government's Delivering Better Financial Outcomespackage and response to the Quality of Advice Review, which includes a number of measures aimed at reducing red tape for professional advisers, including replacing Statements of Advice with a fit-for-purpose advice record, streamlining ongoing fee renewal and consent requirements, and removing the requirement to provide a fee disclosure statement and providing more flexibility on how financial services guide requirements can be met.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5808.
The Government understands the important role cash still plays in our payments system and supports Australians having continued access to cash.

The use of cash as a method of payment has been declining for many years due to changing consumer preferences and advances in technology. This long-run trend has been reinforced by changes in payment behaviour arising from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Nonetheless, cash is an important payment method for certain groups and plays a vital role in their inclusion in the wider economy. Cash is still widely accepted as a means of payment by merchants, used as a store of value, and provides resilience to the payments system during outages where digital forms of money cannot be used.

On 7 June 2023, the Government released its the Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System (the Plan), which details the policy priorities and objectives of the Government in relation to payments.

One of the initiatives in the Plan was 'Maintaining adequate access to cash'. As part of this, the Government will work with relevant agencies across the public sector and with industry to ensure that Australia has a sustainable cash distribution network that maintains adequate access to cash.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Veterans: Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 regarding Parliamentary Petition EN5853, seeking implementation of a standalone opt-in policy by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) where there is an identified need to share a veterans' personal information to any and all third parties, including the University of South Australia.
I understand the concerns within the veteran community regarding the use and sharing of data by DVA with particular reference to the Veterans' Medicines Advice and Therapeutics

Education Services (MATES) program. I assure you this matter is being taken extremely seriously. On 9 February 2024, I asked DVA to close down the MATES program, and examine options for possible future programs that provide health benefits to the veteran community while meeting community and stakeholder expectations around ethical and data use requirements. Proposals such as that put forward in this petition, will contribute to this consideration, which is presently under way.
A copy of the 12 February 2024 statement from the Secretary of DVA is enclosed.

span.span: Statement from the Secretary of DVA on the Veterans' MATES Program

p.span: 12 February 2024

The Department is aware that the withdrawal of Defence and Department of Veterans' Affairs (OVA) Human Research Ethics Committee approval on Monday, 5 February 2024 has increased concerns in the veteran community regarding the Veterans' MATES Program (MATES), particularly in relation to the sharing of data. MATES has sought to support veterans and their families to manage their health and aligns strongly with DVA's objective to proactively support the health and wellbeing of veterans.

It is important to note that there has not been any unauthorised access of veteran data. The data has not been made available publicly or for nefarious purposes. OVA only ever provided client data for the purposes of MATES to a trusted organisation, the University of South Australia (UniSA) under strict data security and access policies.

OVA provided the data to UniSA in accordance with the ethics approvals in place at the time. This was done via a secure and carefully controlled channel. UniSA stored the data in a secure facility. Billing data was automatically de-identified before being accessed by researchers for the thematic review under the MATES program. The data did not include doctor's notes. Identifying data was only used to communicate with the veteran themselves, as well as their doctor, in the event that the analysis of the de- identified data revealed risks to the veteran's health. The letters that went to veterans and their doctors provided invaluable insights that supported those veterans receiving the most appropriate treatment possible.

Following an Office of the Australian Information Commissioner decision in April 2023, an external review was conducted concerning the administration of opt-out procedures in the MATES program. The review concluded all other such requests received by OVA to opt out of MATES had been properly implemented.

OVA takes its obligations under the Privacy Act extremely seriously and in August 2023 paused any provision of data to UniSA to enable a thorough examination of the existing arrangements. Since this time, no data transfers have occurred.
